<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel 1D square-helical coordination polymer [ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was synthesized by the reaction of ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe), while zigzag chains [MX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) were obtained by using smaller anions (Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and larger metal ions (Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Hg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A novel 1D square-helical coordination polymer [ZnI2(μ2-dppe)] n  (1) was synthesized by the reaction of ZnI2 with 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe), while zigzag chains [MX2(μ2-dppe)] n  (2-5) were obtained by using smaller anions (Cl- and Br-) and larger metal ions (Cd2+ and Hg2+).

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel 1D square-helical coordination polymer [ZnI2(μ2-dppe)] n  (1) was synthesized by the reaction of ZnI2 with 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe), while zigzag chains [MX2(μ2-dppe)] n  were obtained by using smaller anions (Cl- and Br-) and larger metal ions (Cd2+ and Hg2+).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The construction of metal–organic coordination polymers is of intense current interest due to their fascinating structures and potential applications in a variety of fields . Among the numerous polymeric architectures, helical structures have attracted much attention for their extensive existence in proteins, collagens, and many natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives. In addition, helices have also shown practical importance in the fields of nonlinear optical devices, biomimetic chemistry, structural biology, etc. . It is acknowledged that the design of organic linkers and choice of metal ions are the keys for the production of specific coordination polymers . However, studies in this subject have focused mainly on organic ligands with classical O-, N-, and S-donors, such as aromatic polycarboxylates and N-heterocyclic ligands , while P-donor ligands are less developed .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The construction of metal-organic coordination polymers is of intense current interest due to their fascinating structures and potential applications in a variety of fields . Among the numerous polymeric architectures, helical structures have attracted much attention for their extensive existence in proteins, collagens, and many natural or artificial fiber-type derivatives. In addition, helices have also shown practical importance in the fields of nonlinear optical devices, biomimetic chemistry, structural biology, etc. . It is acknowledged that the design of organic linkers and choice of metal ions are the keys for the production of specific coordination polymers . However, studies in this subject have focused mainly on organic ligands with classical O-, N-, and S-donors, such as aromatic polycarboxylates and N-heterocyclic ligands , while P-donor ligands are less developed .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Diphosphine agents have long been used in transition metal coordination as either bridging or chelating ligands, which normally depends on the length of the spacer that separates the two phosphorus atoms and the metal ion used . As reported in the literature, the four-membered P–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–P skeleton of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe) is probably an appropriate spacer length that allows the formation of polymers . On the other hand, studies proved that coordination polymers with <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metals (such as Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) may be promising luminescent materials owing to their ability to enhance or shift the luminescent emission of organic ligands upon coordination . In this work, we report the use of the P-donor ligand dppe in the synthesis of supramolecular networks, including a novel square helix and four 1D chains of group 12 metals, [ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [ZnBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), {[CdI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), and {[HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppe)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Diphosphine agents have long been used in transition metal coordination as either bridging or chelating ligands, which normally depends on the length of the spacer that separates the two phosphorus atoms and the metal ion used . As reported in the literature, the four-membered P-CH2-CH2-P skeleton of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (dppe) is probably an appropriate spacer length that allows the formation of polymers . On the other hand, studies proved that coordination polymers with d 10 metals (such as Zn2+ and Cd2+) may be promising luminescent materials owing to their ability to enhance or shift the luminescent emission of organic ligands upon coordination . In this work, we report the use of the P-donor ligand dppe in the synthesis of supramolecular networks, including a novel square helix and four 1D chains of group 12 metals, [ZnI2(μ2-dppe)] n  (1), [ZnCl2(μ2-dppe)] n  (2), [ZnBr2(μ2-dppe)] n  (3), {[CdI2(μ2-dppe)]⋅H2O} n  (4), and {[HgI2(μ2-dppe)]⋅H2O} n  (5).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were obtained by diffusion of the metal halides MX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in water–ethanol (1:20 v/v) and dppe in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. It should be pointed out that, under aerobic conditions, during the reaction of ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with dppe the ligand can be oxidized to form another coordination polymer, [ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-dppeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, where dppeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane dioxide . Therefore, the synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was carried out under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. In all reactions only the 1:1 (M:L) product was obtained even with an excess of the dppe ligand. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are air and moisture stable solids, only slightly soluble in DMSO and insoluble in other common organic solvents.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The coordination polymers 1-5 were obtained by diffusion of the metal halides MX2 in water-ethanol (1:20 v/v) and dppe in CH2Cl2 . It should be pointed out that, under aerobic conditions, during the reaction of ZnI2 with dppe the ligand can be oxidized to form another coordination polymer, [ZnI2(μ2-dppeO2)] n , where dppeO2 is 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane dioxide . Therefore, the synthesis of 1 was carried out under N2. In all reactions only the 1:1 (M:L) product was obtained even with an excess of the dppe ligand. Compounds 1-5 are air and moisture stable solids, only slightly soluble in DMSO and insoluble in other common organic solvents.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>acd</ce:italic>
. The Zn(II) center is coordinated by two phosphorous atoms from two dppe ligands and two terminal iodine atoms with a tetrahedral geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The Zn–P and Zn–I bond lengths (2.3987(19) and 2.5659(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are comparable with the mononuclear ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PPh<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Me)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (2.415(5) and 2.5702(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  and the dinuclear complex Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PEt<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (2.361(5) and 2.532(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . Most interestingly, the dppe ligands function as bridges connecting neighboring Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> cations (Zn⋯Zn separation: 6.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) to form a 1D helical coordination polymer along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. The pitch of the helix containing four dppe ligands and four Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions spans a distance of ca. 21.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The dppe ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a significantly twisted <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation with a P–C–C–P torsion angle of 159.7°, which is rare for the single-bridging dppe ligand reported in the literature . It may be this twist that is responsible for the formation of the helical chain. Both left-handed and right-handed helices are present in the solid, resulting in a racemic structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The nearest Zn⋯Zn separation of the adjacent helical chains is ca. 11.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/acd . The Zn(II) center is coordinated by two phosphorous atoms from two dppe ligands and two terminal iodine atoms with a tetrahedral geometry ( ). The Zn-P and Zn-I bond lengths (2.3987(19) and 2.5659(8)Å) are comparable with the mononuclear ZnI2(PPh2Me)2 (2.415(5) and 2.5702(2)Å)  and the dinuclear complex Zn2I4(PEt3)2 (2.361(5) and 2.532(3)Å) . Most interestingly, the dppe ligands function as bridges connecting neighboring ZnII cations (Zn⋯Zn separation: 6.37Å) to form a 1D helical coordination polymer along the c axis. The pitch of the helix containing four dppe ligands and four ZnII ions spans a distance of ca. 21.1Å. The dppe ligand in 1 shows a significantly twisted trans conformation with a P-C-C-P torsion angle of 159.7°, which is rare for the single-bridging dppe ligand reported in the literature . It may be this twist that is responsible for the formation of the helical chain. Both left-handed and right-handed helices are present in the solid, resulting in a racemic structure ( ). The nearest Zn⋯Zn separation of the adjacent helical chains is ca. 11.9Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The single-stranded helix around the screw axis generates a helical channel. Viewed along the screw axis (<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>), the four zinc atoms in a pitch form a square with a dimension of ca. 3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which is similar to a previously reported rectangular zinc helical channel in [Zn(2,2′-bpy)(1,2-BDC)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (1,2-BDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,2-benzenedicarboxylate) (4.43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) . However, neither isolated solvent molecules nor anions are found in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. There have been many reports on the zinc helices because zinc coordination in DNA domain is a common topic . However, most of the zinc helical polymers reported so far involve O- or N-donating building blocks. Here we have achieved a novel square helix by using a rigid diphosphine (dppe) as the bridging ligand. Unlike many racemates reported , no π–π stacking interactions, hydrogen bonds or other weak interactions have been found in our system.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The single-stranded helix around the screw axis generates a helical channel. Viewed along the screw axis (c) ( ), the four zinc atoms in a pitch form a square with a dimension of ca. 3.5×3.5Å2, which is similar to a previously reported rectangular zinc helical channel in [Zn(2,2'-bpy)(1,2-BDC)(H2O)] n  (1,2-BDC=1,2-benzenedicarboxylate) (4.43×3.48Å2) . However, neither isolated solvent molecules nor anions are found in the crystal structure of 1. There have been many reports on the zinc helices because zinc coordination in DNA domain is a common topic . However, most of the zinc helical polymers reported so far involve O- or N-donating building blocks. Here we have achieved a novel square helix by using a rigid diphosphine (dppe) as the bridging ligand. Unlike many racemates reported , no π-π stacking interactions, hydrogen bonds or other weak interactions have been found in our system.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">When the smaller anion (Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> or Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) was used instead of the iodide ion, or the Zn atom was replaced by its heavier congeners (Cd or Hg), four 1D coordination polymers were obtained. Although their composition [MX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> is very similar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, these compounds have a linear chain structure rather than the helical chain in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Since the compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are isostructural, only <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> will be discussed in detail . Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>. There is a crystallographic inversion center at the midpoint of the ethylene group. The Zn(II) ion is coordinated by two phosphorus atoms from two bridging dppe ligands and two chlorine atoms with a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Zn–P, Zn–Cl bond distances and Cl–Zn–Cl, P–Zn–P bond angles are in the expected range as in some mononuclear Zn(II) complexes such as [ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PMe<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]  and [ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] . The dppe ligand exists as the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> bridging coordination fashion, linking two zinc atoms to form an infinite 1D chain with Zn⋯Zn separations of 7.140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 7.206<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When the smaller anion (Cl- or Br-) was used instead of the iodide ion, or the Zn atom was replaced by its heavier congeners (Cd or Hg), four 1D coordination polymers were obtained. Although their composition [MX2(dppe)] n  is very similar to 1, these compounds have a linear chain structure rather than the helical chain in 1. Since the compounds 2-5 are isostructural, only 2 will be discussed in detail . Compound 2 crystallizes in the space group P21/n. There is a crystallographic inversion center at the midpoint of the ethylene group. The Zn(II) ion is coordinated by two phosphorus atoms from two bridging dppe ligands and two chlorine atoms with a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Zn-P, Zn-Cl bond distances and Cl-Zn-Cl, P-Zn-P bond angles are in the expected range as in some mononuclear Zn(II) complexes such as [ZnCl2(PMe3)2]  and [ZnCl2(PPh3)2] . The dppe ligand exists as the trans bridging coordination fashion, linking two zinc atoms to form an infinite 1D chain with Zn⋯Zn separations of 7.140Å and 7.206Å ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The zinc dibromide compound [ZnBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dppe)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) () is very similar to its dichloride analogue <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, except for the skeleton of the dppe ligand, which is slightly twisted in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with a P–C–C–P torsion angle of 179.4(3)° compared to 180° in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The Zn⋯Zn separation in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (7.576<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is slightly longer than that in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (mean 7.173<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Since the iodide complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a different structure from the chloride and bromide analogues, we examined the reaction of dppe with CdI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> for the purpose to prepare novel helices as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. However, the resultant products exhibit the linear chain structure as in the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The two compounds {[MI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dppe)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cd (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), Hg (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)) are isomorphous, crystallizing in the space group <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:math>. As in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the dppe ligand adopts the perfect <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation (P–C–C–P torsion angle: 180°) due to the presence of the crystallographic inversion center.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The zinc dibromide compound [ZnBr2(dppe)] n  (3) () is very similar to its dichloride analogue 2, except for the skeleton of the dppe ligand, which is slightly twisted in 3 with a P-C-C-P torsion angle of 179.4(3)° compared to 180° in 2. The Zn⋯Zn separation in 3 (7.576Å) is slightly longer than that in 2 (mean 7.173Å). Since the iodide complex 1 has a different structure from the chloride and bromide analogues, we examined the reaction of dppe with CdI2 and HgI2 for the purpose to prepare novel helices as 1. However, the resultant products exhibit the linear chain structure as in the case of 2 and 3. The two compounds {[MI2(dppe)]⋅H2O} n  (M=Cd (4), Hg (5)) are isomorphous, crystallizing in the space group   P   1   ¯    . As in 2, the dppe ligand adopts the perfect trans conformation (P-C-C-P torsion angle: 180°) due to the presence of the crystallographic inversion center.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>Fluorescence properties.</ce:italic> The study of the photochemical properties of coordination polymers is of great interest since such materials often exhibit much higher thermal stability than the corresponding organic ligand, and the fluorescence of the ligand may be tuned by metal coordination . The solid-state emission spectra of free dppe and the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were measured at room temperature. The dppe ligand exhibits an emission band at 435<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 306<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Compared to the free ligand, the compounds show red- or blue-shifted emission bands with significantly enhanced intensities, which are attributed mainly to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The red shift occurs for the iodide complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (479<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), while the blue shift is observed for the chloride and bromide complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (398<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). This is tentatively assigned to the lower transition energies for the iodo-to-metal charge-transfer processes compared to the chloro- or bromo-to-metal transitions . Nevertheless, it is possible that these ligand-to-metal transitions also mix with an intraligand transition. No detectable fluorescence was observed for the Hg(II) complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> under the experimental conditions, indicating a quenching of the fluorescence by the Hg(II) ion via the heavy atom effect . Interestingly, the fluorescent intensity of the cadmium iodide complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is much stronger than that of the zinc iodide <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is probably due to the differences in the metal ion and the structure of the complexes since the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them . The quantum yields (<ce:italic>Ф</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">f</ce:inf>) of the compounds 1–4 are 3.65%, 6.41%, 7.94% and 10.44%, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Fluorescence properties. The study of the photochemical properties of coordination polymers is of great interest since such materials often exhibit much higher thermal stability than the corresponding organic ligand, and the fluorescence of the ligand may be tuned by metal coordination . The solid-state emission spectra of free dppe and the complexes 1-5 were measured at room temperature. The dppe ligand exhibits an emission band at 435nm upon excitation at 306nm. Compared to the free ligand, the compounds show red- or blue-shifted emission bands with significantly enhanced intensities, which are attributed mainly to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The red shift occurs for the iodide complexes 1 (479nm) and 4 (484nm), while the blue shift is observed for the chloride and bromide complexes 2 (394nm) and 3 (398nm) ( ). This is tentatively assigned to the lower transition energies for the iodo-to-metal charge-transfer processes compared to the chloro- or bromo-to-metal transitions . Nevertheless, it is possible that these ligand-to-metal transitions also mix with an intraligand transition. No detectable fluorescence was observed for the Hg(II) complex 5 under the experimental conditions, indicating a quenching of the fluorescence by the Hg(II) ion via the heavy atom effect . Interestingly, the fluorescent intensity of the cadmium iodide complex 4 is much stronger than that of the zinc iodide 1, which is probably due to the differences in the metal ion and the structure of the complexes since the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them . The quantum yields (Ф f) of the compounds 1-4 are 3.65%, 6.41%, 7.94% and 10.44%, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, a novel square helix and four 1D zigzag coordination polymers have been obtained from group 12 metal halides and dppe. The dppe ligand prefers to adopt the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation and act as a bridging rather than chelating ligand, leading to coordination polymers. The fluorescence emission of dppe is effectively enhanced, shifted, or quenched by metal coordination.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel square helix and four 1D zigzag coordination polymers have been obtained from group 12 metal halides and dppe. The dppe ligand prefers to adopt the trans conformation and act as a bridging rather than chelating ligand, leading to coordination polymers. The fluorescence emission of dppe is effectively enhanced, shifted, or quenched by metal coordination.

Supplementary material

   Supplementary material  Experimental procedures.       Crystal structures  Crystallographic data and CIF/PLATON report.     

Compound 1 was synthesized by layering an aqueous ethanolic solution (5mL water-ethanol 1:20 v/v) of ZnI2 (24mg, 0.075mmol) over a solution of dppe (30mg, 0.075mmol) in 5mL of dichloromethane under N2 atmosphere. After six days, X-ray quality single crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 35mg, 62.2%). M.p.>300°C. Anal. Calc. for C26H24I2P2Zn: C, 43.52; H, 3.37. Found: C, 43.51; H, 3.16. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3051 w, 2903 w, 1482 m, 1434 s, 1399 s, 1311 w, 1275 w, 1182 m, 1161 m, 1113 s, 1099 s, 1068 m, 997 m, 880 m, 727 s, 689 s. Compounds 2-5 were synthesized by a similar procedure and the details of the synthesis and characterization are given in the .

cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence properties. The study of the photochemical properties of coordination polymers is of great interest since such materials often exhibit much higher thermal stability than the corresponding organic ligand, and the fluorescence of the ligand may be tuned by metal coordination . The solid-state emission spectra of free dppe and the complexes 1-5 were measured at room temperature. The dppe ligand exhibits an emission band at 435nm upon excitation at 306nm. Compared to the free ligand, the compounds show red- or blue-shifted emission bands with significantly enhanced intensities, which are attributed mainly to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The red shift occurs for the iodide complexes 1 (479nm) and 4 (484nm), while the blue shift is observed for the chloride and bromide complexes 2 (394nm) and 3 (398nm) ( ). This is tentatively assigned to the lower transition energies for the iodo-to-metal charge-transfer processes compared to the chloro- or bromo-to-metal transitions . Nevertheless, it is possible that these ligand-to-metal transitions also mix with an intraligand transition. No detectable fluorescence was observed for the Hg(II) complex 5 under the experimental conditions, indicating a quenching of the fluorescence by the Hg(II) ion via the heavy atom effect . Interestingly, the fluorescent intensity of the cadmium iodide complex 4 is much stronger than that of the zinc iodide 1, which is probably due to the differences in the metal ion and the structure of the complexes since the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them . The quantum yields (Ф f) of the compounds 1-4 are 3.65%, 6.41%, 7.94% and 10.44%, respectively.

 Crystal data for 1 : C26H24I2P2Zn (717.56), tetragonal, space group: I41/acd, a = b =22.6368(14)Å, c =21.1461(13)Å, V =10835.8(12)Å3, Z =16, D calc =1.759gcm-3, F(000)=5536, μ =3.316mm-1, T =293(2)K, 26,355 reflections collected, 2383 independent (R int =0.1347), R1=0.0511, wR2=0.1276 [I >2σ(I)]. Data for 2 : C26H24Cl2P2Zn (534.66), monoclinic, space group P21/n, a =13.022(4)Å, b =11.465(4)Å, c =16.832(5)Å, β =100.173(5)°, V =2473.5(14)Å3, Z =4, D calc =1.436gcm-3, F(000)=1096, μ =1.350mm-1, T =293(2)K, 12,395 reflections collected, 4364 independent (R int =0.0204), R1=0.0292, wR2=0.0732 [I >2σ(I)]. The crystal data and relevant structural parameters of 3-5 are summarized in the  CCDC 746135-746139.
